text: [3.1.1.1 | Option B: Refuse Her]
“No.”
I try to keep my voice steady—like I’m refusing a meal, not refusing someone who’s put their entire existence on me.
“…Why?”
She asks softly, but there’s an uncontained tremor in that softness—like the edge of a blade pressed against glass.
“Because something’s wrong with you.”
“You know me too well. You talk like you’ve already said all of this to me before.”
I hesitate, then say it anyway:
“It scares me.”
She stares at me for a long time.
That look isn’t one of rejection—it’s more like something has once again happened exactly on schedule.
“It’s normal to be scared.”
She actually nods, her tone softening for just a moment.
“You’re scared every time.”
As soon as she says it, she realizes she’s slipped. The corner of her mouth twitches as she forces that *every time* deeper down.
“There it is again. What do you mean by ‘every time’?”
“It means—”
Her throat moves. Like she’s about to tell the truth—and like the truth would drag both of us down with it.
“It means I shouldn’t force you.”
She gathers the candles one by one, her movements slow. She isn’t just putting away candles—it’s like she’s packing away a kind of indulgent hope.
“Then we’ll do it another way.”
“Another way how?”
“You don’t have to eat with me.”
“But tonight, you still need to stay somewhere I can see you.”
She says it too plainly—so plain it sounds like an order, and like a plea.
“And why should I—”
“Because I have a task coming up.”
“I might have to leave this place for a while.”
She pauses, her voice dropping even lower, like she’s talking to herself:
“I don’t want to leave while I’m still just ‘some weirdo’ to you.”
I can’t find any words.
She slips the last candle back into her cloak, like returning a blade to its sheath.
“Forget it.”
“It’s fine if you don’t agree.”
She looks up and suddenly smiles again—there’s something jinx-like in it, like she’s picking a fight with fate.
“I always manage to keep you until nightfall.”
She turns and heads upstairs.
At the stairway, she stops for a second, like she wants to turn back and explain something. In the end, she only leaves one line behind:
“Don’t avoid me.”
